bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Walter Reed, January 1, 1902

div1.p: Kean discusses La Garde's and Havard's candidacy for Surgeon General. There is a question of General Wood's support.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Walter Reed, January 1, 1902
div1.opener:
To Major Walter Reed USA
Private
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA.
OFFICE OF SUPERINTENDENT
DEPARTMENT OF CHARITIES.
HAVANA.
Jan. 1st 1902
div1.p:
A Happy New Year
to you! my friend that
is and chief that is
to be- I found your most
interesting letter of the 6th
of Dec. here on my return
from a tedious trip of
inspections to Puerto
Principe since two weeks
ago- I have been in-
tending ever since to
have a chat with Gen-
Wood but the two or three
2.
times that I have seen
him have been unable
to get him alone- your
story of the origin of our
good friend La Garde's
candidacy is a curious
story- Damn old Westens
eyes, what does he mean
by saying that there isn't
a man above La Garde
that is worth a damn-
If I could not pick
out half a dozen who
are worth the whole
Commissary outfit him-
self included I would
lot my hat. And in the
same letter you tell me
this story and also say
3/
that on account of what
the President said in
his message you think
it may be inadvisable
for you to get letters from
your distinguished scientific
friends! What they think
of your professional quali-
fications stated in a letter
to the A.G. is part of your
record two Westen's advo-
cacy of HavardLa Garge is
personal influence pure
& simple- So if Root
takes that, you can go
ahead & safely get all
the letters you want, &
send them in -- to be filed
as part of your record-
Any man has a right to
4/
do that, and I would
do it if I were you-

Dear old Havard
went away on the 21st
I had not talked to him
of your candidacy but
only to Gorgas who is
a warm backer of yours
when I went down to
see H. off he took me
aside and said that
as the S.G. cy seemed an
open race that, after
a talk with Gen. Wood
and by the advice of the
Cutter, he had determined
to become a candidate
and would like to
have my support-

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA.
OFFICE OF SUPERINTENDENT
DEPARTMENT OF CHARITIES.
HAVANA.

You can imagine my
surprise but I found
my wits enough to say
that his service in Cuba
well entitled him to become
a candidate but that
I was entirely pledged
to support you- Gorgas
joined me a few min-
utes later to told me
that Col. H. had said
the same to him and
that he had replied
substantially as I did-
Gorgas and I are much
puzzled at Col. H's state-
ment that it was by Gen.
6
Woods advice that he be-
came a candidate, for
neither of us will for a
moment believe that the
General has been in
anyway double faced
in the matter, or that he
will really support H.
And if he did not intend
to support him why should
he encourage the dear
old fellow to go in for
a certain disappointment-
And on the other hand
we agreed that H. was
so unimaginative and
matter of-fact that he
was the last person in
the world to assume or
take for granted anything
There is no doubt that the old fellow went
off with the belief that he could count
on General Woods support- So you see
why I am anxious to have a private
chat with the General, and find out if
possible what he did say to the old Col.
AS- for the Generals cordial & hearty
support of you- I do not doubt it
for a moment-

The last ten days has been full of
troubles- It was for me the time to go
on the bimonthly estimates of my institu-
tions- and I had two weeks back office
work to make up- and the North
Altantic Squadron was in port and
there was a function every night- so
between much work & much gaiety and
little sleep the end of the old year
found us a seedy lot- I went to
bed yesterday as soon as I got back
from the office with a fever & an
intercostal neuralgia which was
nearly cutting me in two, and this
afternoon I am just out of bed,
Please give my best wishes for the new
year, in which la shiena jinis- To Mrs Reed
& Miss Blossom & believe me always
